comments.body: Why not write something like `When set to C(yes), the output for I(nodes), I(services) and I(tasks) will contain verbose information ...`?
This is a modified version of description in `docker_host_facts` - used the same template agreed on `docker_node_facts` module for consistency as the module usage is similar

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +68,72 @@  verbose_output:
    description:
      - When set to C(yes) and I(nodes), I(services) or I(tasks) is set to C(yes)
        then output will contain verbose information about objects matching the full output of API method.
        For details see the documentation of your version of Docker API at U(https://docs.docker.com/engine/api/).

comments.body:
How about removing the `docker_` prefix from the return variables, and simplifying the names in general? I would use:
- `swarm_facts` or just `swarm`
- `nodes`
- `services`
- `tasks`

That will break the naming convention of returned values, I am not sure if this is a good idea. Most `docker_*_facts` modules returns variables with `docker_` prefix. Maybe we should open discussion in agenda and unify naming across modules before 2.8 freeze?

Funny thing, the only module which was there already in Ansible 2.7 is `docker_image_facts`, and its return value is called `images` :-) Let's change it in all `_facts` modules, then. I'll create a PR for that.

I am not so sure it is a good approach. I know there is no standard across modules, but it doesn't hurt to have the prefix and it may be useful if you do some manipulations from multiple `_facts` modules from different clouds.
I disagree: if you (as the module's user) want to make sure that you have something around which reminds you of docker, why not put it into the `register:` variable's name then?
Also, let's continue the discussion in #51939.
